instruction: Can the proposed ground-based remote sensing system (GRSS) using spectroscopic methods effectively monitor real-time chlorophyll a concentrations (Chla) in inland waters with high accuracy, addressing the limitations of traditional observations?
Output: Yes, the proposed ground-based remote sensing system (GRSS) using spectroscopic methods can effectively monitor real-time chlorophyll a concentrations (Chla) in inland waters with high accuracy, addressing the limitations of traditional observations. The GRSS consists of three platforms: the spectral measurement platform, the data-processing platform, and the remote access control, display, and storage platform. It is capable of obtaining a remote sensing irradiance ratio (R(lambda)) of 400-1000 nm at a high frequency of 20 s. The system has been calibrated and validated using a dataset of 481 pairs of GRSS R(lambda) and in situ Chla measurements, and it achieved a high performance in deriving Chla with a coefficient of determination (R-2) of 0.95, root mean square error of 13.40 mu g/L, and mean relative error of 25.7%. The GRSS has also successfully captured rapid changes in Chla during phytoplankton bloom events, demonstrating its ability to monitor high-frequency dynamics. Therefore, the GRSS effectively addresses the limitations of traditional observations and provides accurate real-time monitoring of Chla concentrations in inland waters.
